February, 1947, on the subject of a Seamen’s Institute in Bahrain? 2. This question has been a subject of discussion in the past, but no conclusion has been reached since, in my opinion, the most practical way an institute can be established is for BAPCO to build one. They have budgetted in the past for a small building, but the money that can be made available is not sufficient for more than a few rooms which, if the institute Is to be successful, is not adequate. It is difficult for me to take the matter up with BAPCO since the majority of the ships calling at Bahrain ply under foreign flags, and I am not directly concerned with the welfare of their crews. When BAPCO have their own fleet of tankers, as possibly they may do, it will be up to them to provide suitably for their seamen. It Is not only a question of a building but one of staff, both European and native, commissariat, and the Company can hardly be asked to import for persons other than their own employees. 3. As Political Agent T would come into the picture as responsible for the working of the Order-in-Council, and if BAPCO were to build an insticute I should expect them to approach me and to inform me that they were opening an institute which, from its nature, would be available to all seamen. The men should be admitted to a club compound in the BAPCO concession area and supplied with accommodation, food, drink and other amenities. This, I should consider agreeable since the men would be in controlled parties. 4. * If the men are allowed to roam at will over the island, I should certainly not welcome an institute since it would be bound to bring with it complications involving public security. I know from experience in Bahrain that many of the seamen in ships calling here are of a rough type and difficult to handle. Their presence would bring in its wake problems of jails, police, Importation of drink, sexual immorality such as were experienced when troops were stationed on the Island. While all this would be offensive to the Shaikh the solution of these unpleasant problems would devolve on his Government and the Agency Courts. At the present time neither is suffi ciently equipped. /5. From the The Hon’ble Lt-Col. W.R. Hay, C.S.I., C.I.E., political Resident in the Persian Gulf, Bahrain.s* « - 2 - 5. From the charitable aspect, one would like something to be done, but if the Missions to Seamen wish to move in the matter they should approach the Bahrain Government through me, since from the wider point of view the problem is primarily one for the port and not the Oil Company nor the politicals. At Abadan there is a Mission supported by the A.I.O.C. but then that port is used solely by and for the Oil Company which is not the case here. (At Basra the institute is supported by the port). The Mission to Seamen could, of course, approach BAPCO if they pre fer in an endeavour to establish a combined institute which would follow the lines suggested in paragraph 3 above. 6. The suggestion that the Mission should share the services of the proposed Anglican chaplain for Bahrain is a little premature. White might be reminded that what has been done in the direction of obtaining a chaplain for Bahrain has been by lay sub scription and the effort of individuals. The Church Committee has that matter in hand, and may see objection to the appropriation of their chaplain by the Mission. If after' the chaplain is established he finds he has time to give to the Mission so much the better. Or again if the Mission will provide funds to enable anglicans In Bahrain to establish a chaplain then, of course, a proportion of his time would be devoted to Mission work. Or again if the Mission can provide a clergyman to whose stipend the Bahrain Church Fund could contribute he would have to divide his time between the two duties. yours,sincerely, NS.

physicalDescription.extent: The file’s contents are arranged in approximate chronological order, from the earliest item at the front to the latest at the end. The file notes at the end of the file (f 8) mirror the chronological arrangement.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 9; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is present in parallel between ff 3-7; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled, and are located in the same position as the main sequence.

mods.abstract: The file comprises correspondence exchanged between the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf (Lieutenant-Colonel William Rupert Hay) and the Political Agent at Bahrain (Lieutenant-Colonel Arnold Crawshaw Galloway) on the prospect of establishing a seamen’s club and hostel at Bahrain. Included with one letter from Hay, dated February 1947, is a note relating to a conversation between Hay and the Reverend A D White, British Chaplain for Basra and the Persian Gulf and Port Chaplain for the Mission to Seamen. The main points covered in the letters include: the prospects of the Bahrain Petroleum Company (BAPCO) financing and establishing a seamen’s club at Bahrain; possible amenities to be offered at a club; risks associated with allowing seamen access to Bahrain Island; the possible involvement of the Seamen’s Mission in the venture.
